sely for things to work as they should. Biochemical path-
ways require numerous enzymes to interact with one another, in appropri-
ate relative concentrations, so that some important process can occur. If you
imagine a mutation in one of the genes that directs the formation of some es-
sential protein, or if you suppose that the genetic material becomes shuffled
in a way that allows for differences in the rates at which proteins are formed,
it  looks  as  though  disaster  will  ensue.  Crucial
